event.title: was surveyed by George Washington himself in July 1749

data.event: The site of this town was surveyed by George Washington himself in July 1749.
In 1748, Lord Fairfax met a 16-year-old George Washington, a distant relative of his.

event.title: July 24, 1749, the town layout as it appears

data.event: On July 24, 1749, the town layout as it appears today was surveyed and platted by Washington with the assistance of his chainmen John Lonem and Edward Corder as part of his service to Fairfax.
On July 24, 1749, the town layout as it appears today was surveyed and platted by Washington with the assistance of his chainmen John Lonem and Edward Corder as part of his service to Fairfax.

event.title: was officially established as a Town by the Virginia General Assembly on December 14, 1795

data.event: The village was officially established as a Town by the Virginia General Assembly on December 14, 1795 when it gained the requisite population of 200.

event.title: 1835 gazetteer state that the town contained

data.event: Records from an 1835 gazetteer state that the town contained one academy, fifty-five dwellings, four mercantile stores, two taverns, one house of worship, twenty-seven trade shops, and two large flour mills.
